name: limestone quarry operation | limestone, unprocessed | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5188/documentation

This dataset represents the quarry operation of 1 kg of limestone. The dataset includes the land-use for recultivation but not for mining. The size partition of dust emissions were adapted from bauxite mining. Data was normalized using a capacity of about 380'000 tons of product per year.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From limestone at ground, unexcavated.

The activity ends with the limestone quarried. The dataset includes blasting, transports within the mine (for mining and recultivation), heating energy for administration buildings and the infrastructure, and the land-use of the mine. The dataset doesn't include the land-use of the paved roads and buildings within the mine, which are included in the module 'limestone quarry construction' dataset. Output of overburden material neglected as it is only about 0.26% of mined limestone.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/081:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay/0810:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay
tags: Sector: Resource Extraction; Minerals; Cement & Concrete

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data was obtained from Swiss companies.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data corresponds to the high level technology.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is based on a Swiss company (KFN), with a yearly production of  381‘028 t (2001).

exchanges.description:
Limestone is a naturally occurring mineral that consists principally of calcium carbonate but may also contain magnesium carbonate as a secondary component. It is found in many forms and is classified in terms of its origin, chemical composition, structure, and geological formation. Limestone occurs widely throughout the world and is an essential raw material for many industries.
Limestone is generally used for construction, cement, quicklime, agriculture, metal refining and flue gas desulphurisation:

Construction: Limestone is the most widely used crushed rock, although it is generally sold in form of sand and gravel.

Cement: The production of cement is the main use for chalk, and a major use for dense, high-calcium limestone. Approximately 1.1 t of limestone is required for 1 t of cement.

Quicklime: Approximately 1.8 t of limestone is required per 1.0 t of quicklime.

Agriculture: Many crops grow best under neutral to slightly acid conditions (i.e., pH between 6 and 7). Thus soils which are more acidic than pH 6 generally benefit from the application of limestone.

Metal refining: When limestone is used in metal refining it is initially converted to quicklime, which reacts with acidic oxides (e.g., SiO2, Al2O, and Fe2O3) to produce molten slag.

Flue gas desulphurisation: A growing use of limestone is in the treatment of flue gas from combustion processes to remove sulphur dioxide.

Limestone occurs widely throughout the world and is an essential raw material for many industries.
Limestone is generally used for construction, cement, quicklime, agriculture, metal refining and flue gas desulphurisation:

Construction: Limestone is the most widely used crushed rock, although it is generally sold in form of sand and gravel.

Cement: The production of cement is the main use for chalk, and a major use for dense, high-calcium limestone. Approximately 1.1 t of limestone is required for 1 t of cement.

Quicklime: Approximately 1.8 t of limestone is required per 1.0 t of quicklime.

Agriculture: Many crops grow best under neutral to slightly acid conditions (i.e., pH between 6 and 7). Thus soils which are more acidic than pH 6 generally benefit from the application of limestone.

Metal refining: When limestone is used in metal refining it is initially converted to quicklime, which reacts with acidic oxides (e.g., SiO2, Al2O, and Fe2O3) to produce molten slag.

Flue gas desulphurisation: A growing use of limestone is in the treatment of flue gas from combustion processes to remove sulphur dioxide.

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on literature value. It is assumed that there are five mining stages and the mining duration for each stage lasts about 10 years. After that period of time the next stage is tackled and the last is recultivated.
This exchange has an activity link directly to the producing activity because the product is primarily consumed in the same geographical area where it is produced.

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on company data. The input includes the infrastructure needed at mine (buildings, road,...) but not the building machines. A service life of 50 years and a total amount of produced products of 19.051.400.000 kg are assumed.
This exchange has an activity link directly to the producing activity because the product is primarily consumed in the same geographical area where it is produced.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on literature value. The total dust production for limestone mining is 0.16g/kg. The distribution of particle sizes is taken from the process „bauxite mining' (50% of the total dust are > 10microm, 5% < 2.5microm and 45% between 2.5microm and 10microm) as no specific information is available.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on company data. The data considers the total amount of mined limestone for the year 2001. The losses due to dust emissions were neglected.

Estimation, based on literature value. According to the company data reported, it was planned to mine 10'280'000 m3 over 65 years, representing a yearly average amount of mined material about 160'000 m3/a (with a density of 2'300 kg/m3 the amount is 368'000'000 kg/a). Therefore, the total area to be mined over 65 years is 156‘000 m2 or 2'400 m2 per year. The total amount of material excavated per m2 for the year 2001 is therefore about 160’000 kg.

Estimation, based on literature value. According to the company data reported, it was planned to mine 10'280'000 m3 over 65 years, representing a yearly average amount of mined material about 160'000 m3/a (with a density of 2'300 kg/m3 the amount is 368'000'000 kg/a). Therefore, the total area to be mined over 65 years is 156‘000 m2 or 2'400 m2 per year. The total amount of material excavated per m2 for the year 2001 is therefore about 160’000 kg.

Estimation, based on literature value. According to the company data reported, it was planned to mine 10'280'000 m3 over 65 years, representing a yearly average amount of mined material about 160'000 m3/a (with a density of 2'300 kg/m3 the amount is 368'000'000 kg/a). Therefore, the total area to be mined over 65 years is 156‘000 m2 or 2'400 m2 per year. The total amount of material excavated per m2 for the year 2001 is therefore about 160’000 kg. For the occupation calculations, it is assumed that after 13 years te used land is recultivated.

Calculated based on literature, (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). The water used for dust suppression is listed as process water. The evaporation rate is assumed to be 90%. It includes the process of water used for dust suppression in the mine; both off road and on road. The process boundaries are set by the boundaries of limestone mine. The process ends when the raw limestone leaves the mine for further processing. It is assumed that the evaporation rate of process water is 90%. Higher the temperatures are - more dust occurs, more water for suppression is needed, higher the evaporation rate is.
Estimation, based on company data. The total amount of fuel used for heating administration buildings is considered.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on company data. The amount of explosives for blasting used in 2001 is assumed. About half of the used explosives is „Tovex' which is used at the foot of the drilled hole; the upper half is filled with „Amolit'. In general, the types of explosive used in mining can change quickly. However, Tovex explosives are assumed to be used for the total amount.
